byline.contributor: Dave Philipps contributed reporting from New York.

abstract: Four undetonated hydrogen bombs that were accidentally dropped on Palomares, Spain, following crash of United States Air Force bomber in 1966 have scarred village for almost 50 years; release of plutonium from two bombs infected soil, exposing locals and produce to radiation and forcing farmers to remove town's name from labels for fear of stigma (Series: Hydrogen Bombs' Aftermath).

headline.print_headline: An Air Force Bomber Crash Leaves Scars in Spain
headline.main: Even Without Detonation, 4 Hydrogen Bombs From ’66 Scar Spanish Village

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

snippet: Decades after an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, Palomares remains haunted by high radiation levels, a hurried cleanup, health fears and stigma.
lead_paragraph: Decades after an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, Palomares remains haunted by high radiation levels, a hurried cleanup, health fears and stigma.
